ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Prof. Franks provided pre-recorded lecture videos in addition to the virtual seminars. I found these videos quite helpful (sometimes revisiting them three or more times) and would even be glad to see supplementary videos during in-person instruction.

Prof. Franks posted little mini-lectures before class each week. I thought they were WONDERFUL and helpful, and honestly that he should keep doing something along those lines even when the pandemic is over.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course really helps you develop your reading and comprehension skills when it comes to quite difficult pieces of philosophy. The course also covers some of the major works in analytic philosophy during the 20th century.

The nice thing about this kind of material (philosophy in general, particularly the dense phil of language/mind stuff) is that you end up with less "knowledge" than you had coming in. And that's a good thing, probably. 

As for insights? The fact that thought, and language, is possible is totally nuts and amazing; normativity is one of the most basic preconditions that allows us to think at all; recognition of the fact that language isn't simply about propositions throws a wrench in a lot of the Quine/Davidson discussions of radical translation/interpretation, Thomas Kuhn should be taken seriously as a philosopher, not just a historian of science; transcendental arguments matter a lot.

Developed a sharper understanding of the relationship between Kantian and Analytic philosophy and an appreciation of how the latter resolves problems in the former. Appraised the success of Analytic efforts to ground empirical knowledge. Honed my ability to draw unexpected connections between different sources.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor Franks is a great teacher who is able to express complex ideas clearly; the structure of the seminar meetings
Weaknesses: Perhaps more opportunities to interact with our peers by discussing questions in breakout rooms, but this isn't necessarily a weakness
Although the rationality of the roadmap of the course eventually became clear, it wasn't always clear to me where the course was heading or how significant ideas related to the theme of the course.

Strengths: Prof. Franks knows a ton and thinks incredibly deeply about our most basic philosophical assumptions; he guided us through some really, really dense material in a way that, I think, made it as lucid as possible (though I still went through the class feeling as though I understood approximately 40% of what was going on each time).

I think that the material at the end of the course (the Fichte and Cavell, mostly) felt a bit disjointed from the rest of it. Those were the areas where P. Franks wanted to be gain new insights from the new connections he was drawing, I think, which was very cool and thought-provoking, but I think it could have been better developed.

From a purely "how hard do you have to think" perspective, this may have been the single most intellectually challenging course I've taken at Yale. That's both a pro and a con, I guess.

Strengths: fascinating connections drawn between seemingly disparate works in the syllabus (implicitly) and in class (explicitly); the topical focus allowed for cross-communication between Analytic and pre-Analytic schools; clear explication in the supplementary lecture videos. 

Weaknesses: student participation was relatively enfeebled in the first few weeks. While it mounted greatly as we settled in, it was occasionally strained.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I found the pre-recorded videos to be very helpful in introducing the key ideas and general arguments of texts, I thought that the 10 minute breaks during the 2-hour seminar was also helpful.
I was a huge fan of the slides and the pre-class videos. I actually think both could potentially be useful in future classes, even without COVID.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. Although this course covers pretty difficult topics in philosophy, Professor Franks does a great job making these ideas intelligible and clear. Further, this course will truly push you to rethink the grounds ofand the link betweenknowledge and intersubjectivity.
Not for the faint of heart -- but if you're naturally interested in this sort of thing and willing to not understand a lot, it's incredible.
